facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 270 of 1960 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 270 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 21, 1956, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Case Reference No. 4 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 21, 1956, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Case Reference No. 4 of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by SHAH, J. on March 10, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 10. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-

facts.text: Assessees are a firm carrying on business at Kurnool, manufacturing ground-nut oil and cake.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees are a firm carrying on business at Kurnool, of manufacturing ground-nut oil and cake.

facts.text: Under the Madras General Sales Tax Act IX of 1939, assessees entitled to rebate of sales tax paid on goods purchased and used in manufacturing process.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Madras General Sales Tax Act IX of 1939, the assessees were entitled to a rebate of sales tax paid on goods purchased by them and used in the manufacturing process.

facts.text: Assessees maintained books of account according to Samvat Year ending with Diwali, mixture of mercantile and cash system.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees maintained their books of account according to the Samvat Year ending with Diwali. The system of accounting was a mixture of mercantile and cash.

facts.text: Assessees adopted system of paying sales tax calculated on turnover of previous year of account.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees had adopted the system which was permitted by the Act of paying tax calculated on the turnover of the previous year of account.

facts.text: For official year ended 31-3-1942, provisional demand Rs. 2,679, final demand Rs. 1,872, refund Rs. 807.
For official year ended 31-3-1943, provisional demand Rs. 3,046, final demand Rs. 2,863, refund Rs. 183.
For official year ended 31-3-1944, provisional demand Rs. 14,509, final demand Rs. 18,402, additional levy Rs. 3,893.
For official year ended 31-3-1945, provisional demand Rs. 47,276, final demand Rs. 20,037, adjustment Rs. 27,239.
For assessment year 1946-47 corresponding to year of account October 18, 1944 to November 4, 1945, assessees claimed deduction of Rs. 49,633 sales tax paid under provisional assessment.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1946-47  companyresponding to the year of account October 18, 1944 to November 4,1945 , the assessees claimed in their assessment to income-tax to deduct Rs. 49,633

facts.text: In year ending 31-3-1945, assessees paid Rs. 47,276 provisional sales tax, Rs. 3,894 adjustment for previous year, credit Rs. 1,537 rebate, total Rs. 49,633.

anchor.surface_text: In the year ending 31-3-1945, the assessees had paid Rs. 47,276 as sales-tax provisionally assessed. They also had paid in that year Rs. 3,894 in adjustment of the liability for the previous year towards sales-tax due. After giving credit for Rs. 1,537

facts.text: Income-tax Officer accepted the claim of deduction Rs. 49,633 for assessment year 1946-47.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer accepted this claim, and debited it from the income in the assessment year 1946-47 in assessing the taxable income of the assessees.

facts.text: Excess Profits Tax Officer allowed only Rs. 17,055 out of Rs. 47,276 for chargeable period October 18, 1944 to November 4, 1945, disallowing Rs. 30,221 as excess under r. 12 Sch. 1 Excess Profits Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: but for the chargeable accounting period October 18,1944 to November 4, 1945, the Excess Profits Tax Officer allowed out of the amount of Rs. 47,276 debited to sales tax only Rs. 17,055 as properly attributable to that period in companyputing the Excess Profits Tax liability. According to the Excess Profits Tax Officer, the excess amount paid under he provisional assessment i.e., Rs. 30,221

facts.text: Tribunal affirmed the order of Excess Profits Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal against the order of the Excess Profits Tax Officer, the Tribunal affirmed the order.

facts.text: Assessees obtained reference to Andhra Pradesh High Court on question whether materials for Tribunal to hold Rs. 30,221 unreasonable under r. 12 Sch. 1 EPT Act.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order passed by the Tribunal companyfirming the order of the Excess Profits Tax Officer, the assessees applied for and obtained an order referring the following question to the High Court of Judicature of Andhra Pradesh, Whether there are materials for the Tribunal to hold that the aforesaid sales-tax payments of Rs. 30,221 were unreasonable and unnecessary having due regard to the requirements of the business and number companysequently deductible under r. 12 of Sch. 1 of the Excess Profits Tax Act?

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh High Court answered the question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in the negative

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court with leave under s. 66A(2) and (3) Income Tax Act read with s. 21 Excess Profits Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: and against the order of the High Court, this appeal is preferred with leave under s. 66A 2  and  3  of the Income- Tax Act read with s. 21 of the Excess Profits Tax Act.

facts.text: Assessees did not alter their method of accounting year after year.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the assessees had number altered the method according to which their accounts were maintain-Id.

facts.text: Supreme Court held sales tax payments were reasonable and necessary for business under r. 12 Sch. 1 EPT Act.

anchor.surface_text: Payment of sales-tax as assessed being obligatory and necessary for the purpose of carrying on the business, it must in our opinion be deemed to satisfy the requirements of r. 12 of Sch. 1 of the Excess Profits Tax Act.

facts.text: Assessees obliged under s. 10 Madras General Sales Tax Act to pay tax within 15 days of notice, recoverable as land revenue arrears.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 10 of the Madras General Sales Tax Act, the assessees were obliged within 15 days from the date of service of the numberice of assessment to pay tax and in default, the amount was liable to be recovered as if it were an arrear of land revenue.

facts.text: Madras High Court in In re M. P. Kumraswami Raja declared scheme of provisional assessment ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel says that in In re M. P. Kumraswami Raja  1 , the Madras High  1  1955 6 Sales Tax Cases 113. Court has declared this scheme of taxation on provisional assessment ultra Vires.

facts.text: Madras General Sales Tax Amendment Act VIII of 1955 retrospectively validated provisional assessments.

anchor.surface_text: It may also be numbericed that since the Madras High Courts decision in In re Kumaraswami Rajas case  1 , the Madras Legislature by the Madras General Sales Tax Amendment Act VIII of 1955 retrospectively validated the levy.
under r. 12 of Sch. 1 of the Excess Profits Tax Act, expenditure in excess of the amount reasonable and necessary for the business was not a permissible deduction.

arguments.claim: Assessees had not altered their method of accounting; consistently paid provisional tax year after year subject to adjustment, not for evasion

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the assessees had not altered the method according to which their accounts were maintained. Year after year, they were paying tax provisionally assessed by the Sales-tax Officer on the turnover of the previous year subject to adjustment at the close of the year of account. This system of payment of tax under provisional assessments was not adopted with a view to evade tax liability.

arguments.claim: The system of provisional payment was permitted under Madras General Sales Tax Act; liability not voluntarily incurred; payments reasonable and necessary for business

anchor.surface_text: The assessees could opt for the system of paying sales-tax on provisional assessment, but the liability to pay tax imposed was on that account not voluntarily incurred. This system produced no direct benefit to the business and adjudged in retrospect, it undoubtedly reduced the taxable income but if otherwise the payment was reasonable and necessary having regard to the requirements of the business, it was not liable to be ignored

arguments.claim: Reasonableness and necessity of expenditure under r. 12 Sch. 1 EPT Act must be adjudged in the light of commercial expediency

anchor.surface_text: But the reasonableness and necessity of the expenditure sought to be deducted in assessing Excess Profits Tax liability must be adjudged in the light of commercial expediency.

arguments.claim: Payments in discharge of lawful obligation under s. 10 and s. 15 Madras General Sales Tax Act are necessary for business conduct; cannot be unreasonable

anchor.surface_text: The payments made by the assessees were in discharge of obligation imposed lawfully and were necessary for the proper conduct of the business. By s. 10 of the Madras General Sales Tax Act, the assessees were obliged within 15 days from the date of service of the notice of assessment to pay tax and in default, the amount was liable to be recovered as if it were an arrear of land revenue. Again, by s. 15, if the assessees failed to submit the return as required by the provisions of the Act or the rules made thereunder or failed to pay the tax within the time prescribed, they were liable to be penalised.

arguments.claim: Disallowing only tax attributable to period does not disturb assessees' accepted method of accounting

anchor.surface_text: We are also of the view that the Tribunal was in error in holding that by seeking to deduct only the tax properly attributable to the actual turnover during the chargeable accounting period, the Excess Profits Tax Officer was not seeking to disturb the method of accounting which was followed by the assessees and was accepted by the taxing authorities for many years.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: iability to pay tax imposed was on that account number voluntarily incurred. This system produced numberdirect benefit to the business and adjudged in

arguments.claim: Provisional assessment rules under Madras General Sales Tax Act inconsistent/ultra vires; assessees should have challenged before paying; payments not reasonable/necessary

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Commissioner submitted that the rules relating to advance provisional assessment and levy of tax framed under the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 were inconsistent with the provisions of the Act and the assessees should have raised this contention and have obtained a decision from the court before paying tax on provisional assessment and not having done so, payments made cannot be regarded as either reasonable or necessary. Counsel says that in In re M. P. Kumraswami Raja, the Madras High Court has declared this scheme of taxation on provisional assessment ultra Vires.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: service of the numberice of assessment to pay tax and in default, the amount was liable to be recovered as if it were an arrear of land revenue. Again

arguments.court_reasoning: Reasonableness judged by commercial expediency, not legalistic considerations; businessman not expected to litigate valid tax; retrospectively validated

holdings.text: Payment of sales-tax as assessed being obligatory and necessary for the purpose of carrying on the business, it must in our opinion be deemed to satisfy the requirements of r. 12 of Sch. 1 of the Excess Profits Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Payment of sales-tax as assessed being obligatory and necessary for the purpose of carrying on the business, it must in our opinion be deemed to satisfy the requirements of r. 12 of Sch. 1 of the Excess Profits Tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Payments discharge lawful statutory obligations under ss. 10 and 15 MGST Act, necessary for business conduct; satisfy commercial expediency test under r.12 Sch.1 EPT Act.

holdings.text: The Excess Profits Tax Officer was, in our opinion, in error in thinking that the tax paid was in excess of the requirements of the business.

anchor.surface_text: Payment of sales-tax as assessed being obligatory and necessary for the purpose of carrying on the business, it must in our opinion be deemed to satisfy the requirements of r. 12 of Sch. 1 of the Excess Profits Tax Act. The Excess Profits Tax Officer was, in our opinion, in error in thinking that the tax paid was in excess of the requirements of the business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Full provisional payments obligatory per MGST Act; not excess as commercially expedient and statutorily required.

holdings.text: We are also of the view that the Tribunal was in error in holding that by seeking to deduct only the tax properly attributable to the actual turnover during the chargeable accounting period, the Excess Profits Tax Officer was not seeking to disturb the method of accounting which was followed by the assessees and was accepted by the taxing authorities for many years.

anchor.surface_text: We are also of the view that the Tribunal was in error in holding that by seeking to deduct only the tax properly attributable to the actual turnover during the chargeable accounting period, the Excess Profits Tax Officer was not seeking to disturb the method of accounting which was followed by the assessees and was accepted by the taxing authorities for many years.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessees' consistent hybrid accounting method (pay provisional tax per prior turnover) accepted by ITO; proportionate disallowance disturbs it.

holdings.text: But the reasonableness and necessity of the expenditure sought to be deducted in assessing Excess Profits Tax liability must be adjudged in the light of commercial expediency.

anchor.surface_text: But the reasonableness and necessity of the expenditure sought to be deducted in assessing Excess Profits Tax liability must be adjudged in the light of commercial expediency. The payments made by the assessees were in discharge of obligation imposed lawfully and were necessary for the proper conduct of the business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard for r.12 Sch.1 EPT Act deductibility is commercial expediency, applied to find payments reasonable.

holdings.text: But the reasonableness or the necessity of payments under r. 12 Sch. 1 of the Excess Profits Tax Act must be ascertained in the light of what may be regarded as commercially expedient and not on any legalistic considerations.

anchor.surface_text: But the reasonableness or the necessity of payments under r. 12 Sch. 1 of the Excess Profits Tax Act must be ascertained in the light of what may be regarded as commercially expedient and not on any legalistic considerations. It would not be expected of a businessman to start a litigation in respect of a tax which the Legislature of the State was competent to levy on the ground that the method devised for computing the tax liability was ultra vires.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deductibility under r.12 judged by commercial expediency at time of payment, not subsequent ultra vires ruling; no duty to litigate presumptively valid tax; retrospectively validated.

The payments made by the assessees were in discharge of obligation imposed lawfully and were necessary for the proper conduct of the business.

Payment of sales-tax as assessed being obligatory and necessary for the purpose of carrying on the business, it must in our opinion be deemed to satisfy the requirements of r. 12 of Sch. 1 of the Excess Profits Tax Act.
